conclusion: The problem involves finding when the object's velocity is at its maximum based on an acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows acceleration (a) vs. time (t). Acceleration starts at 2 m/s², remains constant until t = 1s, decreases linearly to -2 m/s² at t = 3s, and stays at -2 m/s² until t = 4s.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, and the change in velocity equals the area under the acceleration-time graph. The body starts from rest (v₀ = 0 at t = 0).
For t = 0 to t = 1s, the area under the graph is 2 m/s² × 1s = 2 m/s, so v(1s) = 0 + 2 = 2 m/s.
For t = 1s to t = 2s, the area under the graph is (1/2) × 1s × 2 m/s² = 1 m/s, so v(2s) = 2 + 1 = 3 m/s.
For t = 2s to t = 3s, the area under the graph is (1/2) × 1s × (-2 m/s²) = -1 m/s, so v(3s) = 3 + (-1) = 2 m/s.
For t = 3s to t = 4s, the area under the graph is -2 m/s² × 1s = -2 m/s, so v(4s) = 2 + (-2) = 0 m/s.
The velocity values at different time points are: t = 0s: v = 0 m/s, t = 1s: v = 2 m/s, t = 2s: v = 3 m/s, t = 3s: v = 2 m/s, t = 4s: v = 0 m/s.
The maximum velocity is 3 m/s, which occurs at t = 2s.
The velocity increases from t = 0s to t = 2s due to positive acceleration, stops increasing at t = 2s when acceleration becomes zero, and decreases afterward due to negative acceleration.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2s.
